articles.headline: A Voice Suggests Door-Busters Can Wait
articles.snippet: Anthony Hardwick wanted to spend Thanksgiving with his fiancée and future in-laws. Then Target told him he’d have to show up for work.
articles.abstract: Anthony Hardwick wanted to spend Thanksgiving with his fiancée and future in-laws. Then Target told him he’d have to show up for work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthony Hardwick never thought of himself as an activist or even much of an organizer. He grew up in Kansas City, Mo., graduated from Park University in Missouri in 2009, and looked for a job by scouring the Internet for cities with low unemployment rates. He settled on Omaha, where he found two — as a shopping cart attendant at Target and a printing supervisor for OfficeMax. There he met his fiancée, Denise Holling.

articles.headline: How to Make the Case for Higher Pay
articles.snippet: Companies’ compensation budgets remain tight, so workers need to gather information before approaching the boss.
articles.abstract: Companies’ compensation budgets remain tight, so workers need to gather information before approaching the boss.
articles.lead_paragraph: So you’ve been keeping your head down, working as hard as you can — glad, you tell yourself, that you even have a job.

articles.headline: Banks Build Contingency for Breakup of the Euro
articles.snippet: European leaders say there’s no reason to prepare for the unthinkable: the breakup of the euro zone. But some big banks are no longer so sure.
articles.abstract: European leaders say there’s no reason to prepare for the unthinkable: the breakup of the euro zone. But some big banks are no longer so sure.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the growing chorus of observers who fear that a breakup of the euro zone might be at hand, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has a pointed rebuke: It’s never going to happen.

articles.headline: A New Capital of Call Centers
articles.snippet: Many companies have moved their customer service lines to Manila to take advantage of workers who speak lightly accented English and are familiar with American culture.
articles.abstract: Many companies have moved their customer service lines to Manila to take advantage of workers who speak lightly accented English and are familiar with American culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — Americans calling the customer service lines of their airlines, phone companies and banks are now more likely to speak to Mark in Manila than Bharat in Bangalore.

articles.headline: For U.S., Risks in Pressing Egypt to Speed Civilian Rule
articles.snippet: The Obama administration seems now to be openly trying to position the United States in such a way that regardless of who comes out on top in Egypt, it will keep some credibility.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration seems now to be openly trying to position the United States in such a way that regardless of who comes out on top in Egypt, it will keep some credibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since tens of thousands of protesters converged on Tahrir Square in Cairo for the first Day of Revolution exactly 10 months ago, the Obama administration has struggled to strike the right balance between democracy and stability. In the early morning hours on Friday, President Obama came out on the side of the Arab street, issuing a call for the Egyptian military to quickly hand over power to a civilian, democratically elected government.

articles.headline: Egypt Military Tries to Woo Wider Public to Keep Power
articles.snippet: Egypt’s military is staking its credibility on an ill-defined constituency called the Party of the Couch, which it believes yearns for stability.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s military is staking its credibility on an ill-defined constituency called the Party of the Couch, which it believes yearns for stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Some call it the silent majority. In Egypt these days, the preferred term is the Party of the Couch. And in that ill-defined constituency, sometimes more myth than reality, Egypt’s ruling military has staked its credibility as it seeks to fend off the greatest challenge yet from protesters seeking to force it from power.

articles.headline: For Perry, Life Was Broadened and Narrowed by the Military
articles.snippet: The Air Force took Rick Perry to exotic locales but also cemented his Texas roots and the conservative values that have been central to his political identity.
articles.abstract: The Air Force took Rick Perry to exotic locales but also cemented his Texas roots and the conservative values that have been central to his political identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — Rick Perry arrived on the campus of Texas A&M University in the tumultuous fall of 1968, cut his hair short, regulation military style, and donned a uniform. College students across America were rising up against the Vietnam War, but Mr. Perry, a member of the Corps of Cadets here, would not be among them.

articles.headline: For Obscure Iranian Exile Group, Broad Support in U.S.
articles.snippet: A dozen former top national security officials are among those seeking to reverse the terrorist designation of a group living in Iraq that State Department officials call a repressive cult.
articles.abstract: A dozen former top national security officials are among those seeking to reverse the terrorist designation of a group living in Iraq that State Department officials call a repressive cult.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a time of partisan gridlock in the capital, one obscure cause has drawn a stellar list of supporters from both parties and the last two administrations, including a dozen former top national security officials.

articles.headline: Tensions Flare Between U.S. and Pakistan After Strike
articles.snippet: Saying at least 25 of its soldiers were killed by NATO aircraft, Pakistan closed the alliance’s two main supply routes into Afghanistan and ordered the C.I.A. to vacate drone operations at an air base.
articles.abstract: Saying at least 25 of its soldiers were killed by NATO aircraft, Pakistan closed the alliance’s two main supply routes into Afghanistan and ordered the C.I.A. to vacate drone operations at an air base.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials said on Saturday that NATO aircraft had killed at least 25 soldiers in strikes against two military posts at the northwestern border with Afghanistan, and the country’s supreme army commander called them unprovoked acts of aggression in a new flash point between the United States and Pakistan.
articles.byline: By Salman Masood and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How Freedom Group Became the Big Shot
articles.snippet: In the last few years, many of the top names in rifles and shotguns have been acquired by a corporate unknown: the Freedom Group.
articles.abstract: In the last few years, many of the top names in rifles and shotguns have been acquired by a corporate unknown: the Freedom Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCARBOROUGH, Me.

articles.headline: Slipping Backward on Swaps
articles.snippet: Many on Wall Street, and some in Congress, are pushing back against a proposed rule that aims to promote price transparency in the swaps market.
articles.abstract: Many on Wall Street, and some in Congress, are pushing back against a proposed rule that aims to promote price transparency in the swaps market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALL STREET loves to do business in the shadows. Sunshine, after all, is bad for profits.

articles.headline: A Family’s Billions, Artfully Sheltered
articles.snippet: Ronald S. Lauder, an heir to the Estée Lauder fortune, uses an aggressive tax strategy to preserve holdings that Forbes magazine says make him the world’s 362nd wealthiest person.
articles.abstract: Ronald S. Lauder, an heir to the Estée Lauder fortune, uses an aggressive tax strategy to preserve holdings that Forbes magazine says make him the world’s 362nd wealthiest person.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he stood in the opulent marble foyer of a Fifth Avenue mansion late last month, greeting the coterie of prominent guests arriving at his private art gallery, Ronald S. Lauder was doing more than just being a gracious host.

articles.headline: TV Attack Ads Aim at Obama Early and Often
articles.snippet: Republican presidential candidates and conservative action groups are already spending heavily on television advertising aimed at casting President Obama as a failure.
articles.abstract: Republican presidential candidates and conservative action groups are already spending heavily on television advertising aimed at casting President Obama as a failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the debate halls, the clash may be Republican versus Republican. But offstage, conservatives are mounting a unified and expensive air assault on the candidates’ common opponent: President Obama.

articles.headline: Post-Uprising, a New Battle
articles.snippet: Events in Cairo and across the region in the past week seem as seminal as any since the burst of optimism when the revolts erupted 11 months ago.
articles.abstract: Events in Cairo and across the region in the past week seem as seminal as any since the burst of optimism when the revolts erupted 11 months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Through elections, protests, government formations and armed struggle, Arab countries in an arc from Libya to the gulf were engaged this past week more than ever in attempts not to simply overthrow leaders, but to decisively shape the orders that follow.

articles.headline: Isolating Syria, Arab League Imposes Broad Sanctions
articles.snippet: The group approved a battery of economic sanctions meant to sever most trade and investment from the Arab world, an unprecedented step against a member state.
articles.abstract: The group approved a battery of economic sanctions meant to sever most trade and investment from the Arab world, an unprecedented step against a member state.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Arab League deepened Syria’s international isolation on Sunday by imposing a battery of economic sanctions meant to sever most trade and investment from the Arab world, an unprecedented step against a member state.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Nada Bakri

articles.headline: Time Runs Short for Europe to Resolve Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Each of the possible outcomes for Europe brings with it serious political, legal and financial consequences.
articles.abstract: Each of the possible outcomes for Europe brings with it serious political, legal and financial consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Eighteen months into a sovereign debt crisis — and after many futile efforts to resolve it — the endgame appears to be fast approaching for Europe.

articles.headline: Asset Sale May Be Next for AT&T
articles.snippet: To make buying T-Mobile USA more palatable to regulators, AT&T has to placate the antitrust forces, analysts say.
articles.abstract: To make buying T-Mobile USA more palatable to regulators, AT&T has to placate the antitrust forces, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rethink possible. That is both AT&T’s marketing slogan and an apt summary of the challenges it faces now that its planned $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA looks increasingly doubtful.

articles.headline: Hollywood Labor Fight Looms as Money for Benefits Wanes
articles.snippet: A showdown is expected next spring over financing for some of the most prized perks in show business, the generous health and pension plans.
articles.abstract: A showdown is expected next spring over financing for some of the most prized perks in show business, the generous health and pension plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bitter disputes over health and pension payments to union members have created plenty of drama in states and cities this year. But do not look for a movie about it — Hollywood will be too busy dealing with a labor crisis of its own.

articles.headline: The Branding of the Occupy Movement
articles.snippet: Kalle Lasn, editor of the Canadian magazine Adbusters, did not invent the anger that has been feeding the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations, but he did brand it.
articles.abstract: Kalle Lasn, editor of the Canadian magazine Adbusters, did not invent the anger that has been feeding the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations, but he did brand it.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Kalle Lasn, the longtime editor of the anticonsumerist magazine Adbusters, did not invent the anger that has been feeding the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations across the United States.

articles.headline: A Reporter Entangled in the Story
articles.snippet: Amelia Hill, a reporter for The Guardian in Britain who helped expose phone hacking by newspapers there, found herself questioned by the police.
articles.abstract: Amelia Hill, a reporter for The Guardian in Britain who helped expose phone hacking by newspapers there, found herself questioned by the police.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Amelia Hill, a special investigations correspondent for the British newspaper The Guardian, helped crack open the country’s hacking scandal for all to see. Working with her colleague Nick Davies, she pulled back the veil on the mind-boggling hacking of the murder victim Milly Dowler’s phone by The News of the World.

articles.headline: In Fog of War, Rift Widens Between U.S. and Pakistan
articles.snippet: After a NATO airstrike killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers, actions by the United States and Pakistan reflected a distrust that gets harder to repair with each clash.
articles.abstract: After a NATO airstrike killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers, actions by the United States and Pakistan reflected a distrust that gets harder to repair with each clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The NATO air attack that killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers over the weekend reflected a fundamental truth about American-Pakistani relations when it comes to securing the unruly border with Afghanistan: the tactics of war can easily undercut the broader strategy that leaders of both countries say they share.

articles.headline: For a Weekend, at Least, Retailers See Record Numbers
articles.snippet: American consumers opened their wallets in a way they had not since before the recession, setting records in sales and traffic, but there were signs the gains might not last.
articles.abstract: American consumers opened their wallets in a way they had not since before the recession, setting records in sales and traffic, but there were signs the gains might not last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spurred by aggressive promotions from retailers, American consumers opened their wallets over the holiday weekend in a way they had not since before the recession, setting records in sales and traffic.

articles.headline: Greeks Balk at Paying Steep New Property Tax
articles.snippet: Many Greeks, especially those on small fixed pensions, said they simply had no means to pay a new tax, which does not take income into account.
articles.abstract: Many Greeks, especially those on small fixed pensions, said they simply had no means to pay a new tax, which does not take income into account.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEA IONIA, Greece — Ioannis Chatzis is 86 and lives in a tiny, single room, surviving on a pension that is just enough to pay for food and care for his bedridden wife.

articles.headline: Friend? Foe? A Republican Scorecard
articles.snippet: The Republican candidates seeking the presidential nomination come to the contest bearing years of shared history, relationships — or grudges — just beneath the surface.
articles.abstract: The Republican candidates seeking the presidential nomination come to the contest bearing years of shared history, relationships — or grudges — just beneath the surface.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moments before the start of a recent presidential debate at Dartmouth College, Mitt Romney and Herman Cain flung open the doors to their closet-size green rooms and ran into Newt Gingrich.

articles.headline: In a Surprise, Calm Prevails in Egypt’s Elections
articles.snippet: After a week of violent clashes, the voting was largely peaceful and was hailed by the military as a triumph.
articles.abstract: After a week of violent clashes, the voting was largely peaceful and was hailed by the military as a triumph.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Unexpectedly large crowds of Egyptians on Monday defied predictions of bedlam and violence to cast their votes in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

articles.headline: Dire Warnings Are Building on European Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Despite bleak reports from the O.E.C.D. and Moody’s, investors were optimistic that leaders would find a solution, and markets soared in Europe, Asia and the United States.
articles.abstract: Despite bleak reports from the O.E.C.D. and Moody’s, investors were optimistic that leaders would find a solution, and markets soared in Europe, Asia and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — European leaders faced mounting pressure on Monday to overcome divisions and move ahead quickly with new plans to prevent the euro currency region from fracturing, as warnings multiplied that the crisis could endanger the global economy and cause credit to dry up in the banking system.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Stephen Castle
